Award.AwardTitle: Brighter Futures: Public Deliberation About the Science Of Early Childhood Development.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Through programs (including small group conversations, citizen conferences, and public forums) an interactive exhibition, and two research studies that address issues that are fundamental to establishing museums as places of public dialogue and deliberation, this project will engage the general public, policymakers, and caregivers in deliberations around the latest early childhood development (ECD) research. It will also build on an increased understanding of the importance of ECD to expand civic engagement around this urgent social issue. The overall goal of the project is to help its audiences understand child development, how environment and experiences impact development, and what we as a society can do to support our youngest citizens. Specifically, audiences will explore: How the brain develops from birth until kindergarten (or age five); how a childs environment and experiences sculpt the brain, with some experiences enhancing the child's self-control and learning, and other experiences that actually impede development; and what the project audiences can do to ensure that all children have a strong foundation to learn and thrive.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Brighter Futures: Public Deliberation About the Science Of Early Childhood Development project was a collaboration between the Science Museum of Minnesota (SMM), the Center for Early Education and Development (CEED) at the University of Minnesota, and Public Agenda (PA). The project aimed to:

  • engage museum visitors, policymakers and caregivers in deliberations around the latest early childhood development research
  • build on an increased understanding of the importance of early childhood development
  • expand civic engagement around this urgent social issue

The project met these aims through the development of a museum exhibition, Wonder Years, and related programming.

Wonder Years, opened in SMM’s Human Body Gallery in February 2011 and continues to engage and inform the public in the science of early childhood development. The exhibition focuses on the importance of early experiences and relationships through hands-on activities, images and videos of young children, personal stories and explanations of scientific discoveries. Evaluation studies report that museum visitors enjoy the exhibition, and feel it impacted their thinking about the factors that are important for positive child development. There is also evidence that the project increased participants’ interest and engagement with scientific research and findings about early childhood development. Most of the post-exhibition respondents said they believed they had become more aware of how much science there is in early development.

 The second deliverable included a set of programs that increased community engagement by connecting new visitors to the museum. Some of the programs developed as part of this project include:

Engaging Parents. Parents with young children catalyzed their learning through a visit to the exhibition followed by facilitator led dialogues focusing on parenting, relationships and experiences for young children. This program focused on engaging groups who have less resources or who are first-time museum visitors. Participants in these conversations included parents with children in the HeadStart program, teenaged parents, and parents recently released from correctional facilities.

Connecting to Students. University of Minnesota graduate students extended their learning about our youngest citizens when their classes met at the museum. These visits sought to provide an interactive learning environment on the science of early childhood through a tour of the exhibition followed by a uniquely tailored discussion about the applicability of the exhibit content to participants’ fields of study or professional service. Through these integrative discussions, participants reflected on the information from the exhibit for their own studies and professional careers, as well as how the exhibit might be a useful tool for them in their own work.

Building Community Relationships. After a successful Citizen Conference hosted by the museum in May 2012, project staff continued to meet with an African American Men’s group. This group became the Black Men’s Early Childhood Project, a group that encourages black men to be more involved in the lives of young children. The group continues to visit the exhibition, work with Minnesota’s ACES initiative, and host community conversations.
